questions.article: Portable video game consoles and wireless speakers tend to contain batteries that can’t be easily ______. Environmental policy researcher Jessika Richter warns that because new batteries can’t be put in once the old ones no longer work, the gadgets stop functioning and are usually disposed of as trash.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: rated

options.name: B
options.content: invented

options.name: C
options.content: prevented

options.name: D
options.content: replaced

questions.correct: replaced

questions.article: Whether Carmen Lomas Garza is creating small paintings and illustrations or large public artworks—such as Baile, a copper cutout of traditional Mexican dance in the San Francisco International Airport—she is ______ direct experience, drawing from memories of her childhood in Texas or details of her current surroundings in California.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: complimented by

options.name: B
options.content: uncertain about

options.name: C
options.content: unbothered by

options.name: D
options.content: inspired by

questions.correct: inspired by

questions.article: Domesticated thousands of years ago by Indigenous people in South America, the potato deviates structurally from the wild plant it is descended from. Summer squash, another crop domesticated by Indigenous Americans, shows so little resemblance to any wild plant that genetic research was necessary to ______ the wild Johnny gourd as its ancestor.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: confirm

options.name: B
options.content: acquire

options.name: C
options.content: develop

options.name: D
options.content: attract

questions.correct: confirm

questions.article: When considering which plays and musicals to produce, theaters in San Francisco often favor keeping audiences happy over taking risks. So while they might be eager to produce an established classic like Amadeus, for example, most would be ______ to stage a work from a relatively unknown playwright.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: determined

options.name: B
options.content: hesitant

options.name: C
options.content: fortunate

options.name: D
options.content: surprised

questions.correct: hesitant

questions.article: When classical pianist Martha Argerich performs, it appears as if the music is coming to her spontaneously. She’s highly skilled technically, but because of how freely she plays and her willingness to take risks, she seems relaxed and natural. Her apparent ease, however, is due to a tremendous amount of preparation. Despite Argerich’s experience and virtuosity, she never takes for granted that she knows a piece of music. Instead, she approaches the music as if encountering it for the first time and tries to understand it anew.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To provide details about Argerich identifies which pieces of music she will perform.

options.name: B
options.content: To assert that Argerich’s performances look effortless because of how she prepares for them.

options.name: C
options.content: To discuss the kinds of music Argerich feels most comfortable encountering for the first time.

options.name: D
options.content: To describe the unique way that Argerich approaches music she hasn’t performed before.

questions.correct: To assert that Argerich’s performances look effortless because of how she prepares for them.

questions.article: Dubautia waialealoe is a species in a family of plants known collectively as the silversword alliance, all of which grow only on the Hawaiian Islands. Members of this alliance exhibit an extraordinary range of phenotypes, with some species maturing into vines and others into shrubs and trees. All species in the alliance descended from a single ancestral tarweed plant that arrived on the islands around 5 million years ago. The tarweed’s descendants diversified into distinct species as they adapted to live in the wide variety of habitats found on the Hawaiian Islands.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined phrase in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It lists species from a family of plants found only on the Hawaiian Islands.

options.name: B
options.content: It provides the common name for the Dubautia waialealoe plant.

options.name: C
options.content: It explains why Dubautia waialealoe is unique among members of the silversword alliance.

options.name: D
options.content: It supplies the name used to refer to a group of related plant species.

questions.correct: It supplies the name used to refer to a group of related plant species.

questions.article:
The following text is adapted from Jerome K. Jerome’s 1889 novel Three Men in a Boat (To Say Nothing of the Dog).

We [people] are creatures of the sun. We love light and life. That is why we crowd into the towns and cities, and the country grows more and more deserted every year. In the sunlight—in the daytime, when Nature is alive and busy all around us, we like the open hill-sides and the deepwoods well enough: but in the night, when our Mother Earth has gone to sleep, and left us waking, oh! the world seems so lonesome, and we get frightened, like children in a silent house. Then we sit and sob, and long for the gas-lit streets, and the sound of human voices, and the answering throb of human life.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To indicate that people sometimes experience feelings of isolation in crowded areas.

options.name: B
options.content: To address common traits that motivate many people to choose to live in urban environments.

options.name: C
options.content: To caution people not to be so quick to dismiss the natural beauty that can be found in rural areas.

options.name: D
options.content: To demonstrate that most people tend to prefer being alone in the country to being alone in towns or cities.

questions.correct: To address common traits that motivate many people to choose to live in urban environments.

questions.article:
Text 1
According to a study by a conservation group representing 11 tribal nations in the Great Lakes region, the northern pike (ginoozhe in the Ojibwe language) will have significantly worse outcomes over the next 50 years if temperatures increase as much as some models suggest. By contrast, the white-tailed deer (Waawaashkeshi in Ojibwe) should be able to withstand the highest predicted warming without much harm and so likely won’t require the conservation efforts that the northern pike will.

Text 2
US government agencies involved in conservation are unfortunately not able to address every possible threat to natural resources. They must use the best information available to decide which species are most threatened and therefore most in need of conservation efforts.
questions.question: Based on the texts, both authors would most likely agree with which statement?

options.name: A
options.content: A collaborative approach is necessary to keep temperatures in the Great Lakes region from increasing to the highest predicted levels.

options.name: B
options.content: Agencies involved in natural-resource management in the Great Lakes region should focus their conservation efforts more on the northern pike than on the white-tailed deer.

options.name: C
options.content: Conservation efforts focused on the northern pike are more likely to be successful if they incorporate state and federal agency resources with the knowledge of tribal groups in those efforts.

options.name: D
options.content: State, federal, and tribal groups involved in natural-resource management in the Great Lakes region should immediately begin conservation programs for both the northern pike and white-tailed deer.

questions.correct: Agencies involved in natural-resource management in the Great Lakes region should focus their conservation efforts more on the northern pike than on the white-tailed deer.

questions.article: The ancient writing system used in the Maya kingdoms of southern Mexico and Central America had a symbol for the number zero. The earliest known example of the symbol dates to more than 2,000 years ago. At that time, almost none of the writing systems elsewhere in the world possessed a zero symbol. And the use of zero in Mexico and Central America may be even more ancient. Some historians suggest that Maya mathematicians inherited it from the Olmec civilization, which flourished in the region 2,400–3,600 years ago.
questions.question: According to the text, what do some historians suggest about Maya civilization?

options.name: A
options.content: Maya civilization acquired the use of zero from the Olmec civilization.

options.name: B
options.content: Maya civilization respected its historians more than it respected its mathematicians.

options.name: C
options.content: Maya civilization was highly secretive about its intellectual achievements.

options.name: D
options.content: Maya civilization tried to introduce its writing system to other civilizations.

questions.correct: Maya civilization acquired the use of zero from the Olmec civilization.

questions.article: In Costa Rica, use of solid fuel (e.g., coal, wood) as a share of total household fuel use fell by approximately 60 percent between 2000 and 2019; such shifts are typically explained by appeal to the energy ladder, a model holding that fuel choice is mediated mainly by household income (specifically, high-technology fuels displace solid fuels as incomes rise). Rasmus Heltberg’s study of fuel use in Guatemala shows how reductive this model is, however, household fuel use was heterogeneous, flexible, and influenced by several factors, including the local prices of different fuel sources.
questions.question: Based on the text, which choice best explains why the author characterizes the energy ladder as “reductive”?

options.name: A
options.content: The energy ladder asserts that households only consider one aspect of fuel when making fuel choices, but Heltberg’s study showed that households ignore that characteristic of fuel and evaluate several other factors instead.

options.name: B
options.content: The energy ladder holds that the adoption of one type of fuel means that another type of fuel must be displaced, but Heltberg’s study showed that several different fuel types are typically used in equal proportion.

options.name: C
options.content: The energy ladder assumes that the same factor influences household fuel choice in all locations, but Heltberg’s study showed that fuel choice in Guatemala is influenced by different factors than is fuel choice in Costa Rica.

options.name: D
options.content: The energy ladder attributes household fuel choice primarily to a single characteristic of households, but Heltberg’s study showed that multiple circumstances can affect household fuel choice.

questions.correct: The energy ladder attributes household fuel choice primarily to a single characteristic of households, but Heltberg’s study showed that multiple circumstances can affect household fuel choice.

questions.article: “The Bet” is an 1889 short story by Anton Chekhov. In the story, a banker is described as being very upset about something: ______
questions.question: Which quotation from “The Bet” most effectively illustrates the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: “Then the banker cautiously broke the seals off the door and put the key in the keyhole.”

options.name: B
options.content: “It struck three o’clock, the banker listened; everyone was asleep in the house and nothing could be heard outside but the rustling of the chilled trees.”

options.name: C
options.content: “The banker, spoilt and frivolous, with millions beyond his reckoning, was delighted at the bet.”

options.name: D
options.content: “When [the banker] got home he lay on his bed, but his tears and emotion kept him for hours from sleeping.”

questions.correct: “When [the banker] got home he lay on his bed, but his tears and emotion kept him for hours from sleeping.”

questions.article:
Minimum and Maximum Depths of Stony Coral Species in Caribbean and Indo-Pacific Waters

Some scientists have suggested that as ocean temperatures rise, many fish and corals found in the shallow zone (less than 30 meters below the surface) could take refuge in the cooler, darker mesophotic zone (30 to 150 meters below the surface). However, it isn’t clear that all such species will be able to tolerate mesophotic conditions. In 2018, Luiz Rocha and colleagues studied stony corals in the two zones in Caribbean and Indo-Pacific waters. Based on the depths at which those corals are now found, the species that seems least suited to a full migration to the mesophotic zone is ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the statement?

options.name: A
options.content: Acropora striata, because its maximum depth of 25 meters is close to but doesn’t reach the mesophotic zone.

options.name: B
options.content: Porites nodifera, because its maximum depth of 15 meters is furthest from the mesophotic zone.

options.name: C
options.content: Agaricia grahamae, because its minimum depth of 20 meters is in the shallow zone.

options.name: D
options.content: Polillopora meandrina, because its minimum depth of 1 meter is the shallowest of those listed.

questions.correct: Porites nodifera, because its maximum depth of 15 meters is furthest from the mesophotic zone.

questions.article: Water flowing around an obstruction creates vortices (patterns of swirls) of varying size; by detecting the vortices, fish can determine the size and position of the obstruction. Testing by Yuzo R. Yanagisuru, Otar Akanyeti, and James C. Liao using models of three head shapes—narrow (low ratio of width to length), intermediate, and wide (high ratio of width to length)—showed that for large vortices, fish with intermediate heads would be better able than narrow-headed fish to distinguish between vortices and general turbulence in the water. A second research team has therefore hypothesized that in low-visibility conditions, intermediate-headed fish will be more likely than narrow-headed fish to detect obstructions that create large vortices.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly support the second research team’s hypothesis?

options.name: A
options.content: A study using obstructions that created large vortices in low-visibility conditions found that the intermediate-headed Lobocheilos rhabdoura bumped into the obstructions just as often as the narrow-headed lookdown (Selene vomer) did.

options.name: B
options.content: A study using obstructions that created large vortices in low-visibility conditions found that the lookdown (Selene vomer), which has a relatively narrow head, bumped into more than half of the obstructions.

options.name: C
options.content: A study using obstructions that created large vortices in low-visibility conditions found that the narrow-headed lookdown (Selene vomer) bumped into obstructions more often than the intermediate-headed Lobocheilos rhabdoura did.

options.name: D
options.content: A study using obstructions that created large vortices in low-visibility conditions found that some specimens of the intermediate-headed Lobocheilos rhabdoura bumped into the obstructions more often than other specimens of the same fish did.

questions.correct: A study using obstructions that created large vortices in low-visibility conditions found that the narrow-headed lookdown (Selene vomer) bumped into obstructions more often than the intermediate-headed Lobocheilos rhabdoura did.

questions.article: In a college course on urban affairs, a student asserts that traffic congestion in the United States increased between 1990 and 2000 mostly in and around very large cities such as New York City, New York. The student claims that not only were smaller areas such as Allentown-Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, and Beaumont, Texas, affected by traffic congestion but in very large cities such as New York City, New York, this congestion also worsened over time.
questions.question: Which choice best describes data from the graph that support the second student’s claim?

options.name: A
options.content: In all three urban areas shown, the amount of traffic delay per commuter per year was greater in 2000 than in 1990.

options.name: B
options.content: In at least one of the three urban areas shown, the amount of traffic delay was less than 20 hours per commuter per year at one point between 1990 and 2000.

options.name: C
options.content: Throughout the period between 1990 and 2000, the amount of traffic delay per commuter per year was greater in the Allentown-Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, area than in the New York City, New York, area.

options.name: D
options.content: In 1992, the amount of traffic delay in the New York City, New York, area was less than 30 hours per commuter per year.

questions.correct: In all three urban areas shown, the amount of traffic delay per commuter per year was greater in 2000 than in 1990.

questions.article: Mariana Lopes Barata and Pedro Simões Coelho collected data from 324 music-streaming service users to identify factors that influence users to opt for paid (premium) versions of music streaming services, like Spotify. They hypothesized that performance expectancy (how much the use of a service is perceived to benefit the consumer) would be positively correlated with users’ intentions to adopt premium versions. The researchers asked participants to rate statements such as “Overall, a paid music streaming service is advantageous.” They found that, indeed, performance expectancy positively influences the intention to adopt premium streaming service versions, which suggests that ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: users’ intentions to pay for premium steaming services are probably unaffected by factors other than performance expectancy.

options.name: B
options.content: participants who strongly agreed with the statement “Overall, a paid music streaming service is advantageous” were more likely to express loyalty to Spotify than to other streaming services.

options.name: C
options.content: the statement “Overall, a paid music streaming service is advantageous” is not a reliable measure of performance expectancy.

options.name: D
options.content: it may be advantageous for music streaming companies to try to influence the extent to which potential users perceive the use of the premium version to be beneficial.

questions.correct: it may be advantageous for music streaming companies to try to influence the extent to which potential users perceive the use of the premium version to be beneficial.

questions.article: Technologies such as microphones and inkjet printers are made using piezoelectric materials, which generate an internal electric field when pressure is applied to them. The toxic nature of some of these materials recently led a team from the University of Sheffield to investigate how ______
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: could their use be better regulated?

options.name: B
options.content: their use could be better regulated.

options.name: C
options.content: their use could be better regulated?

options.name: D
options.content: could their use be better regulated.

questions.correct: their use could be better regulated.

questions.article: Upper Fruitland Chapter is one of the 110 chapters of the Navajo Nation (Naabeehó Bináhásdzo). The chapter, whose boundaries encompass 83,400 acres, _______ known as Doo alk’ aai in the Navajo language (Diné bizaad).
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: are

options.name: B
options.content: have been

options.name: C
options.content: were

options.name: D
options.content: is

questions.correct: is

questions.article: While the greater adjutant can be found in places like Hakaluki Haor in Bangladesh and Northern Santuk in Cambodia, more than 80 percent of this endangered stork species is found in Assam, India. There, wildlife biologist Dr. Purnima Devi Barman is on the front lines of conservation efforts that—through community involvement and scientific ______ aim to bring adjutants back from near extinction.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: study—

options.name: B
options.content: study,

options.name: C
options.content: study:

options.name: D
options.content: study

questions.correct: study—

questions.article: National Heritage Areas like the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia ______ officially designated by the United States Congress as being “unique [and] nationally significant” for their natural, cultural, and historical attributes.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: has been

options.name: B
options.content: are

options.name: C
options.content: was

options.name: D
options.content: is

questions.correct: are

questions.article: On March 23, 2021, a gust of wind wreaked havoc on global trade. Ever Given, an international shipping container vessel, became lodged in Egypt’s Suez Canal, a major shipping route between Europe and Asia. The vessel took six days to ______ it’s as heavy as two thousand blue whales when fully loaded.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: dislodge in part due to its sheer size,

options.name: B
options.content: dislodge, in part due to its sheer size:

options.name: C
options.content: dislodge, in part due to its sheer size,

options.name: D
options.content: dislodge, in part, due to its sheer size

questions.correct: dislodge, in part due to its sheer size:

questions.article: Just as the state of Hawaii has a designated state flower, tree, and bird, it also has a state soil: Hilo soil. Hilo is a fitting choice for state soil, in large part because it can be found in abundance across the state. ______ it plays an important role in Hawaii’s agricultural industry and is used to grow a variety of crops, like ginger and taro.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: Alternatively,

options.name: B
options.content: By contrast,

options.name: C
options.content: At that time,

options.name: D
options.content: Additionally,

questions.correct: Additionally,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • In the 1930s, the Imperial Sugar Cane Institute in India sought to limit the country’s dependence on imported sugarcane.
  • The institute enlisted botanist Janaki Ammal to breed a local variety of sugarcane.
  • She crossbred the imported sugarcane species Saccharum officinarum with grasses native to India.
  • She succeeded in creating sugarcane hybrids well suited to India’s climate.
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize Janaki Ammal’s achievement. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: By crossbreeding the imported sugarcane species Saccharum officinarum with grasses native to India, Ammal succeeded in creating sugarcane hybrids well suited to India’s climate.

options.name: B
options.content: In the 1930s, the Imperial Sugar Cane Institute, which enlisted Ammal, sought to limit dependence on imported sugarcane.

options.name: C
options.content: Ammal was enlisted by the Imperial Sugar Cane Institute at a time when a local variety of sugarcane needed to be produced.

options.name: D
options.content: As part of efforts to breed a focal variety of sugarcane, an imported sugarcane species called Saccharum officinarum was crossbred with grasses native to India.

questions.correct: By crossbreeding the imported sugarcane species Saccharum officinarum with grasses native to India, Ammal succeeded in creating sugarcane hybrids well suited to India’s climate.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Richard Serra is an American artist.
  • He is known for his large metal sculptures.
  • His sculpture Cycle is roughly 62 feet wide and 56 feet tall.
  • It is made from weathering steel.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize the size of the sculpture?

options.name: A
options.content: Richard Serra is an American artist known for his large metal sculptures.

options.name: B
options.content: Cycle—a large metal sculpture by artist Richard Serra—stretches roughly 62 feet wide and 56 feet tall.

options.name: C
options.content: American artist Richard Serra creates large sculptures from metals such as weathering steel.

options.name: D
options.content: Richard Serra’s Cycle is made of weathering steel.

questions.correct: Cycle—a large metal sculpture by artist Richard Serra—stretches roughly 62 feet wide and 56 feet tall.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Dinosaur fossil specimens can be found at science museums all over the world.
  • A dinosaur fossil specimen nicknamed Jane is housed at the Burpee Museum of Natural History in Rockford, Illinois.
  • Jane, a Tyrannosaurus, lived in the Late Cretaceous period.
  • A dinosaur fossil specimen nicknamed Fafnir is housed at the Science Museum of Minnesota in Saint Paul, Minnesota.
  • Fafnir, a Triceratops, lived in the Late Cretaceous period.
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize a similarity between the two dinosaur fossil specimens. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Both the Tyrannosaurus fossil specimen Jane and the Triceratops fossil specimen Fafnir lived in the Late Cretaceous Period.

options.name: B
options.content: While the Tyrannosaurus fossil specimen Jane is in Rockford, Illinois, the Triceratops fossil specimen Fafnir is in Saint Paul, Minnesota.

options.name: C
options.content: The Burpee Museum of Natural History is home to Jane, a Tyrannosaurus fossil specimen from the Late Cretaceous period.

options.name: D
options.content: Dinosaur fossil specimens can be found at science museums all over the world, including in Rockford, Illinois, and Saint Paul, Minnesota.

questions.correct: Both the Tyrannosaurus fossil specimen Jane and the Triceratops fossil specimen Fafnir lived in the Late Cretaceous Period.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The Future of Nostalgia is a scholarly book by literary theorist Svetlana Boym.
  • The book explores the concept of nostalgia from various angles.
  • Chapter 1 outlines the origins and use of the term nostalgia.
  • Chapter 17 discusses various skeptics’ takes on the concept of nostalgia.
  • In chapter 17, Boym writes, “The poethics of nostalgia combines estrangement and human solidarity, affect and reflection.”
questions.question: The student wants to explain what Svetlana Boym writes about in chapter1. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Literary theorist Svetlana Boym outlines the origins and use of the term nostalgia in chapter 1 of her book.

options.name: B
options.content: As Svetlana Boym writes in the seventeenth chapter of her book, “The poethics of nostalgia combines estrangement and human solidarity, affect and reflection.”

options.name: C
options.content: After outlining the origins and use of the term nostalgia, Svetlana Boym goes on to discuss various skeptics’ takes on the concept of nostalgia.

options.name: D
options.content: Svetlana Boym’s The Future of Nostalgia explores the concept of nostalgia from various angles.

questions.correct: Literary theorist Svetlana Boym outlines the origins and use of the term nostalgia in chapter 1 of her book.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The poem “5 love haiku” is by African American writer Sonia Sanchez.
  • It was published in her 2010 poetry book entitled Morning Haiku.
  • The poem is written as a sequence of five haiku.
  • According to the book’s publisher, Penguin Random House (PRH), the book “celebrates the gifts of life and mourns the deaths of revered African American figures.”
  • According to Sanchez, she chose to write in the form of haiku because it helps “maintain memory and dignity.”
questions.question: The student wants to provide an example of a poem from Morning Haiku. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Included in Sanchez’s poetry book Morning Haiku (2010), “5 love haiku” is a poem written as a sequence of five haiku.

options.name: B
options.content: Sanchez chose to write in the form of the haiku because it helps “maintain memory and dignity.”

options.name: C
options.content: The 2010 poetry book Morning Haiku “celebrates the gifts of life and mourns the deaths of revered African American figures.”

options.name: D
options.content: The poem by Sanchez is written as a sequence of five haiku.

questions.correct: Included in Sanchez’s poetry book Morning Haiku (2010), “5 love haiku” is a poem written as a sequence of five haiku.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • A river’s stream length is the length of a line that follows along the river path.
  • A river’s valley length is the length of a straight line drawn from the beginning of the river to the end.
  • The river’s curviness, or sinuosity, is the ratio of the river’s stream length to its valley length.
  • This ratio is less than or equal to 1.5:1 in low-sinuosity rivers and greater than 1.5:1 in high-sinuosity rivers.
  • The Fort Nelson River in Canada has high sinuosity.
  • The Wadi Al-Hamd River in Saudi Arabia has low sinuosity.
questions.question: The student wants to compare the sinuosity of the Fort Nelson and Wadi Al-Hamd rivers. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: While the high-sinuosity Fort Nelson River is located in Canada, the Wadi Al-Hamd River is in Saudi Arabia.

options.name: B
options.content: In both the Fort Nelson and the Wadi Al-Hamd rivers, sinuosity is determined by comparing stream length to valley length.

options.name: C
options.content: The ratio of the Fort Nelson River’s stream length to its valley length is greater than 1.5:1, exceeding that of the Wadi Al-Hamd River.

options.name: D
options.content: By comparing the stream lengths of the Fort Nelson and Wadi Al-Hamd rivers to their valley lengths, one can calculate their sinuosity.

questions.correct: The ratio of the Fort Nelson River’s stream length to its valley length is greater than 1.5:1, exceeding that of the Wadi Al-Hamd River.
